title: Best of Late Night: Trump's friends and associates plan
text:
CLOSE President Donald Trump's treatment of his friends and associates leaves much to be desired. Mike Thompson, Detroit Free Press

The late night comics point out that President Trump's idea of friendship leaves a lot to be desired

There don't seem to be many advantages to joining President Donald Trump's friends and associates plan. The president is notorious for throwing just about anyone under the bus if it suits his needs. It's a habit that continues to create havoc with US foreign policy and the late night comics have taken note.

Trevor Noah points out that Trump's erratic foreign policy has left our friends and allies in the Middle East in a lurch. The president's willingness to "flip" on his own vice president didn't escape Stephen Colbert's notice. Jimmy Kimmel pokes fun at Trump's ever-changing loyalty to his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, a trait that Saturday Night Live's Kate McKinnon picks up on in her hilarious impersonation of the former mayor of New York.

Trevor Noah works on the set of "The Daily Show" on Sept. 29, 2015 in New York. (Photo: Evan Agostini/Invision/AP)
